tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"This is for the director of music to use in worship"
This probably tells what musical style or tune to use when singing the psalm. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:057:001|57:1]].
Possible meanings are 1) David wrote the psalm or 2) the psalm is about David or 3) the psalm is in the style of David's psalms.

The meaning of the word "michtam" is uncertain. You may use the word "psalm" instead. This can be written as: "This is a psalm that David wrote." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:016:001|16:1]].

tn.ref: when Saul sent, and they watched the house to kill him
tn.text: "from when Saul sent his soldiers to go and watch David's house for an opportunity to kill him"
A high place represents a safe place where his enemies cannot reach him. AT: "put me in a safe place" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Rising up against someone represents attacking him. AT: "attack me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The word "bloodthirsty" contains "blood," which refers to murder and "thirsty," which refers to desire. AT: "people who desire to kill" or "people who like to kill people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: they wait in ambush to take my life
tn.text: David's enemies are in hiding and are waiting quietly for the time when they can attack him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Deciding to do something and beginning to do it is spoken of as waking up.  AT: "do something" or "take action" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
What he wants God to see can be stated clearly. AT: "and see what is happening to me" or "and see what they are doing to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Deciding to do something and beginning to do it is spoken of as getting up. AT: "do something" or "take action" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The word "nations" here represents the people of the nations that do not honor God. AT: "the people of all the nations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The word "they" refers to the wicked transgressors.

The psalmist speaks of his enemies threatening to attack people as if they were dogs howling, growling, or barking at people. AT: "they threaten to attack people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Why they go around the city can be stated clearly. AT: "go around the city to attack anyone they find" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here the word "See" is being used to draw attention to something. AT: "Hear"

tn.ref: they belch out with their mouths
tn.text: Saying terrible things is spoken of as belching. These terrible things may have been insults or threats. AT: "they say terrible things" or "they shout out terrible words" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
burp loudly; allow air from the stomach to come out of the mouth with a loud, rude noise

The cruel things that the wicked people were saying are spoken of as if they were swords. AT: "they say cruel things that cause people trouble as much as swords destroy people"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This question is used to show that they believed that God would not hear and punish them. AT: "No one can hear us!" or "Your God does not hear us!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"laugh at them scornfully" or "mock them." God would laugh at them because they are worthless and powerless.

tn.ref: you hold all the nations in derision
tn.text: "you ridicule all the nations" or "you know that the people of the nations are fools"
"ridicule" or "mockery"
God's being the psalmist's strength represents God protecting him. AT: "you are my strength" or "you are my protector" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

A high tower is a place that people could go to for shelter from their enemies. The psalmist speaks of God protecting him as if God were a strong, safe shelter. AT: "you protect me like a high tower" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
God's rescuing the psalmist is spoken of as if God were to meet him. AT: "My God will rescue me"
The abstract noun "desire" can be expressed with the verb "want." AT: "what I want to happen to my enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"Cause them to wander around"
God's protecting the righteous is spoken of as if God were a shield. AT: "our protector" or "the one who protects us like a shield" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: For the sins of their mouths and the words of their lips
tn.text: The mouths and lips represent the things people say.  AT: "Because they sin by what they say" or "Because of the sinful things they say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: let them be captured in their pride
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "let people capture them because of their pride" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"that they say"

tn.ref: Consume them in wrath, consume them so that they will be no more
tn.text: Destroying them completely is spoken of either as burning them up or eating them. AT: "Be angry with them and destroy them completely so there will be no more of them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Jacob here refers to Israel. AT: "in Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: to the ends of the earth
tn.text: "to even the most distance places on earth." This represents all places on earth. AT: "everywhere on earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The psalmist speaks of his enemies threatening to attack people as if they were dogs howling, growling, or barking at people. AT: "threatening to attack us" or "threatening to attack us like wild dogs" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"content"

tn.ref: you have been my high tower and a refuge
tn.text: High towers and refuges are places that people can go to for shelter from their enemies. The psalmist speaks of God protecting him as if God were a strong, safe shelter. AT: "you have protected me like a high tower and a refuge" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: in the day of my distress
tn.text: The word "day" here refers to a period of time. AT: "whenever I have had troubles" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: To you, my strength, I will sing praises
tn.text: "To you, my strength" can be combined as one clause. AT: "You are my strength, so I will sing praises to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_sentences]])
God's being the psalmist's strength represents God protecting him. AT: "my protector" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: for God is my high tower
tn.text: High towers are places that people can go to for shelter from their enemies. The psalmist speaks of God protecting him as if God were a strong, safe shelter. AT: "you have protected me like a high tower"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This can be expressed in a separate sentence. AT: "He is the God of covenant faithfulness" or "You are the God of covenant faithfulness"
